awd_titl_txt: Digitization TCN: Collaborative Research: The Cretaceous World: Digitizing Fossils to Reconstruct Evolving Ecosystems in the Western Interior Seaway
awd_abstract_narration:
Between 65 and 100 million years ago, during the time that dinosaurs walked the earth, a large, tropical seaway covered the central part of what is now North America. This seaway teemed with marine life. Snails and clams lived on the seafloor; ammonites, along with giant mosasaurs, plesiosaurs, sharks, and fish, swam about; at the same time early birds and pterosaurs floated on or flew above the seaway. What remains today is a prolific fossil record that has been collected by paleontologists for over 100 years. Notable fossils from this time period and region are on display at museums around the world. However, the vast bulk of fossils collected from this region are locked away in museum drawers. To provide scientists and the general public access to these fossils and their associated data, this project proposes to digitize invertebrate and vertebrate fossils from this time period and region, making information accessible through searchable electronic databases. Additionally, a variety of online resources illustrating and describing these fossils and mapping their distributions will be developed. A freely accessible online textbook of paleontology will be generated and a website and App will be developed to highlight the appearances, occurrences, and ages of constituent species, to help students and aspiring paleontologists identify and learn about these fossils. The project plans to generate a variety of curricular materials for K-12 education, including 3-D scans of fossils for free download and printed 3-D models for classroom use. Products of this project will also include workshops to engage science teachers and items to augment public programs and exhibits at participating institutions. 

This work will greatly increase the scientific value of eight major U.S. museum collections of fossils. The museum collections contain large amounts of data useful for studying what causes marine species to migrate, go extinct, and evolve during a long period of greenhouse climate conditions similar to those our planet may soon experience. These data have relevance for evaluating how global change has and will continue to affect life on earth. An estimated 164,000 specimens collected from thousands of locations, in the region once occupied by the Western Interior Seaway, will be databased and georeferenced. Representatives from each of roughly 1,500 microfossil, invertebrate, and vertebrate species will be imaged. The digitized records will be made available online via individual museum databases, iDigBio, and iDigPaleo. The resultant data will enable scientists to answer questions about how different species interact and ecosystems change in the face of environmental shifts during a key time in the history of life. Moreover, the data will be ideal for use with an assortment of modern quantitative tools -including paleoecological niche modeling (PaleoENM) - and will help improve paleoclimate and paleoceanographic models. Finally, several undergraduate and graduate students will be trained. Results of the project will be published at the following url: www.digitalatlasofancientlife.org.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
As a result of this multi-institutional collaborative project, we have significantly increased the accessibility and extent of information on the fossil specimens stored in our collections.  Databasing this information in a standardized format makes it possible to share it online for use by others for research and education.  The focus of our project was to database Cretaceous fossils along the Western Interior Seaway in North America.  This time and place are significant as a key interval of warm greenhouse conditions and changing sea-levels that serve as a proxy for studying biotic responses to environmental disturbances.  For the University of Texas's contribution on this project, we databased more than 25,000 relevant Cretaceous catalogued records representing about 81,000 invertebrate specimens in the Non-vertebrate Paleontology collection and almost 2,000 relevant marine Cretaceous records in the Vertebrate Paleontology collection of the Jackson School Museum of Earth History.  Across all collaborators in this project, more than 475,000 specimens were databased.  As part of this effort, we georeferenced occurrences (generated latitude and longitude values and ranges) for mapping almost 5,900 fossil localities; overall more than 25,000 localities were georeferenced across the entire project. In addition, almost 12,000 specimens were imaged and attached to our Specify database.  The specimen and locality data are publicly accessible at www.iDigBio.org, www.GBIF.org, and our Specify web portals: http://specify-portal.tacc.utexas.edu/npl/ and http://specify-portal.tacc.utexas.edu/vpl/.  

Data from our collections has already been downloaded and used as supported by website metrics and citations in several publications related to marine fossil species abundance, diversity, geographic distribution, and extinction.  Students at the University of Texas have also contributed to and used data from these Cretaceous records for their research, such as on the extinct aquatic reptiles of the Mosasauridae and on inoceramids, a group of invertebrate bivalves.  Over the course of this project, we trained and supported four graduate students, and over fifteen undergraduate students and community volunteers from diverse backgrounds.  Participants learned and performed a variety of skills broadly applicable to many fields such as digital imaging, data management, and georeferencing. 

As part of this project, we also developed a software component, Paleomap, to be used with the Specify database program.  It allows modern day latitude and longitude values of a paleontological specimen to be mapped to land masses as they were positioned at the time of fossil deposition.  This is available to all natural history collections that use Specify and enables paleontological researchers to better understand spatial biogeography and specimen distributions during different times of the past.  With our collaborators, we also shared descriptions, images, and maps online about many fossil species we databased through the Cretaceous Atlas of Ancient Life, https://www.cretaceousatlas.org/, the Digital Atlas of Ancient Life, http://www.digitalatlasofancientlife.org/, and its mobile application, https://www.digitalatlasofancientlife.org/version-2-0-of-the-digital-atlas-of-ancient-life-app/.


Last Modified: 03/25/2022
Modified by: Lisa D Boucher
por.por_txt_cntn:
As a result of this multi-institutional collaborative project, we have significantly increased the accessibility and extent of information on the fossil specimens stored in our collections.  Databasing this information in a standardized format makes it possible to share it online for use by others for research and education.  The focus of our project was to database Cretaceous fossils along the Western Interior Seaway in North America.  This time and place are significant as a key interval of warm greenhouse conditions and changing sea-levels that serve as a proxy for studying biotic responses to environmental disturbances.  For the University of Texas's contribution on this project, we databased more than 25,000 relevant Cretaceous catalogued records representing about 81,000 invertebrate specimens in the Non-vertebrate Paleontology collection and almost 2,000 relevant marine Cretaceous records in the Vertebrate Paleontology collection of the Jackson School Museum of Earth History.  Across all collaborators in this project, more than 475,000 specimens were databased.  As part of this effort, we georeferenced occurrences (generated latitude and longitude values and ranges) for mapping almost 5,900 fossil localities; overall more than 25,000 localities were georeferenced across the entire project. In addition, almost 12,000 specimens were imaged and attached to our Specify database.  The specimen and locality data are publicly accessible at www.iDigBio.org, www.GBIF.org, and our Specify web portals: http://specify-portal.tacc.utexas.edu/npl/ and http://specify-portal.tacc.utexas.edu/vpl/.  

Data from our collections has already been downloaded and used as supported by website metrics and citations in several publications related to marine fossil species abundance, diversity, geographic distribution, and extinction.  Students at the University of Texas have also contributed to and used data from these Cretaceous records for their research, such as on the extinct aquatic reptiles of the Mosasauridae and on inoceramids, a group of invertebrate bivalves.  Over the course of this project, we trained and supported four graduate students, and over fifteen undergraduate students and community volunteers from diverse backgrounds.  Participants learned and performed a variety of skills broadly applicable to many fields such as digital imaging, data management, and georeferencing. 

As part of this project, we also developed a software component, Paleomap, to be used with the Specify database program.  It allows modern day latitude and longitude values of a paleontological specimen to be mapped to land masses as they were positioned at the time of fossil deposition.  This is available to all natural history collections that use Specify and enables paleontological researchers to better understand spatial biogeography and specimen distributions during different times of the past.  With our collaborators, we also shared descriptions, images, and maps online about many fossil species we databased through the Cretaceous Atlas of Ancient Life, https://www.cretaceousatlas.org/, the Digital Atlas of Ancient Life, http://www.digitalatlasofancientlife.org/, and its mobile application, https://www.digitalatlasofancientlife.org/version-2-0-of-the-digital-atlas-of-ancient-life-app/.
